awd_titl_txt: DMREF/Collaborative Research: A Data-Centric Approach for Accelerating the Design of Future Nanostructured Polymers and Composites Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Polymer nanocomposites are highly tailorable materials that, with careful design, can achieve superior properties not available with existing materials. Most polymer nanocomposites are developed using an Edisonian (trial and error) process, severely limiting the capacity to optimize performance and increasing time to implementation. The solution is a data-driven design approach. As an example, this Designing Materials to Revolutionize and Engineer our Future (DMREF) project will design new material systems that simultaneously optimize for dielectric response and mechanical durability, a combination currently not achievable but necessary for high voltage electrical transmission and conversion. These new materials will have a significant economic impact on society because they will enable higher efficiency generation and transmission of electricity.  More broadly, this new design approach will result in new nanostructured polymer material systems that will impact a wide range of industries such as energy, consumer electronics, and manufacturing.  To ensure broad access to this work, the data, tools and models developed will be integrated and shared through an open data resource, NanoMine. The team will interact with the scientific community to create an integrated virtual organization of designers and researchers to test and improve the models. Educational components will reach undergraduate and graduate communities via interdisciplinary cluster programs at the two institutions, and provide undergraduate research opportunities and web based instructional modules and workshops.

The research is based on a central research hypothesis that using a data-driven approach, grounded in physics, allows integration of models that bridge length scales from angstroms to millimeters to predict dielectric and mechanical properties to enable the design and optimization of new materials. Data, algorithms and models will be integrated into the new and growing nanocomposite data resource NanoMine to address challenges in data-driven material design. This research will result in advancements in three areas. First, integrating a broad set of literature data and targeted experiments with multiscale methods will enable the development of interphase models to predict local polymer properties near interfaces considered critical for modeling polymer composites. Second, a hybrid approach utilizing machine-learning to bridge length scales between physics-based modeling domains will be used to create meaningful multiscale processing-structure-property relationship work flows. And, third, a Bayesian inference approach will utilize the knowledge contained in a dataset as a prior probability distribution and guide 'on-demand' computer simulations and physical experiments to accelerate the search of optimal material designs. Case studies will demonstrate the data-centric approach to accelerate the development of next-generation nanostructured polymers with predictable and optimized combinations of properties.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Making and Measuring Nanodielectric materials

We have created a design method for nanodielectric materials. These are materials that have small amounts of nanoparticles (very small particles measuring less than 100nm in length or width) mixed into polymers (plastics). The composite material can have improved performance for electric charge storage due to the many interfaces and their tunability. Nanodielectrics have many useful applications, such as making better insulators, batteries, and electronics that are thin, light, and flexible. We have learned two important things from our work: 1) how to make the nanoparticles distribute evenly in the polymers, which can help improve the quality and efficiency of the nanomaterials. 2) how to measure and control the electric properties of the thin layers (interfaces) between the nanoparticles and the polymers, which can help us design nanomaterials with specific functions and performance. We have found that the way the nanoparticles distribute in the polymers depends on how well they interact with each other, and how we process them. We have made a design map that shows how the nanoparticles distribute based on these factors. We have also used a unique microscope (called EFM) that can detect the electric forces at the interfaces. We have shown that this method can help us understand and measure the responses at the interfaces in nanodielectric materials.

Multiscale Computer simulations and data analysis

Prediction and design of nanodielectric materials is a complex task because many factors influence their properties, with important effects across a wide range of scales, from electronic to millimeter dimensions. We developed computer simulations to predict the dielectric breakdown strength, which is the critical electric field at which the material loses insulating capabilities. We considered many factors, such as the shape and distribution of the particles in the materials, and the variety of thin interphase layers around the nanoparticles to help us understand how to design better materials. There are significant challenges in modeling these materials, especially when it comes to the interface region surrounding the particles, which add complexity to the design process, and the simulations needed are computationally intensive. We used a combination of experimental data and computer simulations to overcome these challenges. We also developed a machine learning model that can predict the properties of these materials based on these factors. Our study provides a framework that incorporates all of these factors to predict and design materials with insulating properties. Our framework can help us design better nanodielectric materials for critical applications.

Designing materials for specific applications

Using the above framework, we focused on designing polymer nanocomposites that can store charge well and have high breakdown strengths. We used a technique called multicriteria optimization to find the best materials designs for a given set of desired property targets. This technique helps us maximize the strength of the material and its ability to store electrical energy while minimizing lts energy loss. We used computer simulations to test different designs and found that our method can identify many different designs that work well. These designs are mapped on the “Pareto frontier”, which shows the tradeoffs between different properties of the material. Our study shows that using data and computer simulations is an efficient way to design new nanodielectrics. In another study, we designed materials that can store electrical energy using elongated nanoparticles. Our technique helps us understand how different factors influence the properties of the material. We found that by adding nanoparticles to the material that are moderately long and are layered with charge-trapping molecules, we can increase the strength and permittivity (energy storage) of the material while limiting the amount of energy loss. By using mixed-variable global sensitivity analysis, we gained a deeper understanding of how different microstructural and interface choices impact the overall performance of nanodielectrics.
Another study examined the relationship between the glass transition temperature (a characteristic temperature where plastics transition between being stiff/glassy to being soft/rubbery upon heating) and key characteristics of both the nanofillers and the polymer matrix. This study leveraged data from over 2000 experimental samples curated within the MaterialsMine database. This study used feature importance to first identify the key factors related to glass transition temperature and then trained machine learning metamodels to  predict the glass transition temperature change due to the particles. This study shows that by using large amounts of data, we can learn more about how materials work and how to design better materials.

Overall, our research provides a framework for designing better nanodielectric materials for energy storage applications and makes new scientific discoveries possible.


Last Modified: 12/31/2023
Modified by: Ravishankar Sundararaman
